_prev_prog_3.Description: The RMP prevention program at Agri-Mark is a safety management system used to identify, evaluate and control hazards, which could contribute to catastrophic releases of highly hazardous chemicals.  Agri-Mark implements this program by following, at a minimum, the specific prevention program elements identified in the RMP regulation and the OSHA PSM.

_exec_summary.SummaryText:
1.1 DISCUSSION

If a facility handles, manufactures, uses in a process or stores any of the toxic or flammable substances listed in 40 CFR ?68.130 above the specified threshold quantities, the facility is required to develop and implement a Risk Management Program.  The Risk Management Program rule was issued and is administered by the U.S. Environmental Protection Agency (EPA). This rule, ?Chemical Accident Prevention (CAP) Provisions? (Part 68 of Title 40 of the Code of Federal Regulations (CFR)), applies to a wide variety of facilities that handle, manufacture, store or use toxic and/or highly flammable substances.

Agri-Mark stores 12,900 pounds of ammonia at their manufacturing facility on 869?Exchange Street in Middlebury, Vermont.  Agri-Mark is required to address the requirements of the CAP regulations because they exceed the 10,000 pound ammonia threshold. 

Agri-Mark owns and operates the Middlebury facility, which produces cheese and other dairy related products.  The purpose of the ammonia is as a heat transfer medium for the facility?s refrigeration system.  A total of 12,900 pounds of ammonia is maintained in the closed loop refrigeration system.

Agri-Mark is also subject to the Process Safety Management (PSM) standard under the Occupational Safety and Health Administration (OSHA) regulation 29?CFR 1910.119.  The State of Vermont has been delegated authority for OSHA compliance.  There are also a number of other chemicals used at the facility, which are addressed in Agri-Mark?s EMERGENCY RESPONSE Plan.

The Risk Management Plan contains the Policies and Procedures used at Agri-Mark to assure continued compliance with the EPA CAP and OSHA PSM regulations.  Most of the documents that are part of the Risk Management Plan follow a standard format that includes the purpose, organization, responsibilities and authorities, as well as general step-by-step instructions.  Section references are shown throughout this document in ALL CAPITAL LETTERS for referenc

e purposes.

Most procedures contain information on document control and filing.  Typically, documents are periodically revised through the procedures outlined in SECTION 9 - MANAGEMENT OF CHANGE.  

All employees are strongly encouraged to review the Risk Management Plan?s policies and procedures.  The manual is available for review by any employee at any time.  Any recommendation to improve a document?s accuracy or effectiveness in assuring employee, visitor and contractor safety can be directed to management.

The goal of the Risk Management Plan is to prevent accidental releases of substances that can cause serious harm to the public and the environment from short-term exposures and to mitigate the severity of releases that do occur. The 1990 Amendments to the Clean Air Act (CAA) required EPA to issue a rule specifying the type of actions to be taken by facilities to prevent accidental releases of hazardous chemicals into the atmosphere and to reduce their potential impact on the public and the environment. 

The phrase "Risk Management Program" refers to all of the requirements of Part 68, which must be implemented on an on-going basis. The phrase "Risk Management Plan" refers to this document as well as the registration information submitted to EPA.  In general, the Risk Management Plan requires that:

* Covered facilities must develop and implement a Risk Management Plan and maintain documentation required by the plan on site.  The Risk Management Plan will include an analysis of the potential offsite consequences of an accidental release, a five-year accident history, a release prevention program and an emergency response program.

* Covered facilities also must submit registration information (RMP Submit) to EPA no later than June 21, 1999 or the date on which the facility first has more than a threshold quantity in use or stored at the site, whichever is later.  Covered facilities are also required to re-submit their Risk Management Plans every five years.

The RMP Submit provides an electronic summary of the facility?s Risk Management Plan.

* Covered facilities also must continue to implement the Risk Management Program and update their Risk Management Plans periodically or when processes change, as required by the rule.

Section 2 - Management System

The implementation and management responsibilities for the Plan must be clearly defined.  This section discusses various duties that must be addressed in order to fulfill the intent of the Plan.  This section also describes the employee responsibilities associated with each duty.  

Mr. Bernie Boudreau, Plant Manager, and his designees are identified throughout this document as the Risk Management Program Coordinators (RMPC).

Section 3 - Hazard Assessment

A major component of the Risk Management Plan is the assessment of impacts associated with the accidental release of regulated substances.  This section evaluates both the worst-case release as well as alternative releases that are specific to the site.

The analysis focused on the impact to neighboring areas called receptors.  Receptors include residences, schools, parks, prisons, commercial buildings, etc.  Graphic as well as tabulated exhibits help to define the impact of accidental releases.

Based on guidelines provided by EPA in the 2004 RMP Submit Instruction Manual, release scenario information is not provided in this Executive Summary.

Section 4 - Process Safety Information

Process Safety Information (PSI) is a repository for information related to the safety of a process.  Three major subjects addressed in this section are:

* The hazards of the chemicals and the process (physical properties, toxicity and exposure limits, fire and explosion characteristics, reactivity data, thermal and chemical stability, corrosivity data).

* The process technology (process chemistry, process flow diagrams, safe operating limits, maximum intended inventories, consequences of deviation).

* Equipment information (pipin

g and instrumentation diagrams, material and energy balances, safety systems involved, materials of construction, electrical classification, relief system design and design basis, ventilation system design and design basis, design codes and standards employed).  This information is used as a reference during Process Hazards Analyses.

Documentation is found primarily in the Material Safety Data Sheets (MSDS), the Risk Management Plan and the Process Safety Information files.  

Section 5 - Process Hazard Analysis

Process Hazard Analysis (PHA) is a systematic approach toward evaluating the safety of a process.  PHAs must address the hazards of a process, previous incidents having potential for serious consequences, engineering and administrative controls, facility siting, human factors and an evaluation of the range of exposures if controls fail.  If there is more than one process, a schedule for completing PHAs must be formulated and be based on the extent of process hazards, the number of potentially affected employees, the age of the process and the operating history of the process.  Employees must have input into the prioritization of PHAs and this schedule must be fully communicated to all employees.  PHAs must follow a standard methodology, such as a What If/Checklist Analysis and be performed by a cross-functional team with at least one person who is familiar with the process, at least once every five years.  A system for addressing, resolving, documenting and communicating all recommendations in a prompt manner must also be in place.

Typical documentation should include information on how PHA studies were prioritized, employee briefings on the PHAs, a copy of each PHA file index and evidence of how PHA recommendations were completed.  These PHA files include the pertinent process safety information.

The original PHA was conducted on August 25, 1999 and included representatives from Agri-Mark, Tighe & Bond and various contract firms which designed the ammon

ia system, designed the ammonia system controls and service the refrigeration system.  The five year PHA update was conducted on July 21, 2004 by the following participants.

Agri-Mark
Tighe & Bond
* David Brault - Engineering

* Jeff Flora ? Health and Safety / Operations

* James Galenkamp - Maintenance
* Michael Matilainen, CIH, CSP - Facilitator

* Adam Lomartire ? Scribe / Assistant
Based on guidelines provided by EPA in the 2004 RMP Submit Instruction Manual, release scenario information is not provided in this Executive Summary.

The Agri-Mark personnel present during the PHA were those that have the greatest expertise on the ammonia system and its technical systems.  Tighe & Bond personnel selected for the PHA were those who conducted the initial PHA in 1999.

Section 6 - Operating Procedures

Operating procedures are instructions that outline how to safely operate a process consistent with Process Safety Information.  They must be appropriate, clear, consistent and well communicated.  Procedures must address steps for each operating phase (initial startup, normal operations, temporary operations, emergency shutdown, emergency operation, normal shutdown, startup after a turnaround), operating limits (consequences of deviation, steps to correct or avoid) and safety and health considerations (properties/hazards of chemicals, precautions to avoid exposure, control measures in the event contact occurs, quality control, inventory control, special or unique hazards, safety systems & their function).  Procedures must be accessible and certified to be correct at least annually.  Safe work procedures must exist for hot work, lock-out/tag-out, confined space entry, opening process equipment/piping and controlling entry to storage and distribution areas, for both employees and contractors.

Typical documentation should include evidence that employees had input to the content and format of Operating Instructions, an index of all Operating Instructions, completed Confine

d Space Entry permits, completed Lock-out/Tag-out Program audit forms, etc.  Copies of the Operating Instructions are kept in the Operating Procedure File.

Tighe & Bond personnel visited the facility on August 25, 1999 to investigate and document standard operating procedures for the ammonia and propane operation.  Operators at the facility reviewed and commented on draft procedures developed by Tighe & Bond.  The Operators comments are included in the final procedures incorporated into the Risk Management Plan.

Operating procedures are reviewed on an annual basis by Agri-Mark.  Substantive changes to the procedures are noted in a controlled manner.  If substantial changes to the ammonia system require revision to the operating procedures, such changes are tracked through the management of change process.

Section 7 Employee Training Program

Initial training must be provided for employees involved with Risk Management Program processes that cover an overview of the process, specific safety and health hazards, emergency operations including shutdown and other safe work procedures that may be applicable.  For existing employees, the employer must document that operators have the required knowledge and do not need initial training.  Refresher training must be provided periodically that covers understanding and adherence to current operating procedures.  Records must be kept that verify that an employee has received and understood the training; these records must include employee identification, date of training and method of verification.

Documentation is found primarily in the Training Files.  This file should contain evidence that employees had input into retraining frequency and other aspects of the training program.

Initial regulatory training was provided on March 8, 1999.  Additional ammonia and propane hazard and emergency response training was performed on April 9, 1999.  The training outlines and evaluation quizzes can be found in the facility?s Process S

afety file.

Refresher training was provided to applicable Agri-Mark employees on October?24,?2002 during the facility?s Hazardous Waste Operations and Emergency Response (HAZWOPER) Hazardous Material Technician refresher.  In accordance with the CAP regulations, the next refresher training must be conducted by October 24, 2005.

Section 8 - Mechanical Integrity Program

Written procedures have been developed for maintaining the ongoing integrity of process equipment.  Mechanical Integrity (MI) applies to pressure vessels and storage tanks; piping systems and their components; relief and vent systems and associated devices; emergency shutdown systems; controls (sensors, alarms, interlocks); and pumps.  Employees involved with MI must be trained in an overview of the process and in specifics of the job task.  Inspection/testing must be performed using generally recognized and accepted good engineering practices, at a frequency consistent with manufacturer?s recommendations or good engineering practices (or more frequently if warranted).  Inspections must be documented and include date, person performing test, equipment identifier, test description and results of test or inspection.  Deficiencies outside acceptable limits must be corrected before further use or corrected in a safe and timely manner, provided that the hazards of continued operation are properly addressed.  Employers must certify that new equipment is fabricated and installed in a suitable manner for the process and in accordance with manufacturer?s instructions and design specifications.  Employers must certify that maintenance materials, spare parts and equipment are suitable for the process.

Documentation is found primarily in the Training and Maintenance files.  The Training File should contain all maintenance personnel training records; the Maintenance files should contain all inspection records, deficiency reports, etc.

Agri-Mark certifies that their ammonia system was designed in accordance wit

h recognized engineering standards at the time of construction and during any subsequent renovations to the system.  The systems were also inspected during the Process Hazard Analysis.  The facility follows the manufacturer?s recommendations for inspection and maintenance found in the Operations and Maintenance Manuals.

Section 9 - Management of Change

A system is used to properly manage changes to process chemicals, technology, equipment and procedures.  The Management of Change (MOC) form must include the technical basis for the change; impact of the change on employee safety & health; modifications to operating procedures; modifications to Process Safety Information; time period involved; and authorization requirements.  Employees and contractors must be informed of the change prior to implementation.

Typical documentation should include MOC worksheets (including employee review sheets) and documentation from any training meetings required for a particular MOC.  The Agri-Mark Risk Management Plan maintains a procedure and forms necessary to manage change.  Agri-Mark implements the MOC process whenever making changes to the ammonia system or the Risk Management Plan that is not replacement-in-kind.

Section 10 Pre-Startup Safety Review

The Pre-Startup Safety Review (PSSR) is a review of new or significantly modified processes prior to introducing a highly hazardous chemical.  The review includes confirmation that construction and equipment are in accordance with design specifications; that safety, operating, maintenance and emergency procedures are in place; that the action items have been addressed; and that training of employees is complete.

Typical documentation should include any specific training performed for hazard review team members prior to their participation in a preliminary hazard review or pre-startup safety review.  The review documentation is filed in the PSSR File and should include evidence of how recommendations were implemented; these file

s also include any pertinent process safety information.

While there have been numerous additions and improvements to the ammonia refrigeration system since the Risk Management Plan was initiated in August 1999, there have been no changes to the system, which require a formal PSSR.

Section 11 - Compliance Audits

Employers must certify that they have evaluated facility compliance with the Risk Management Program at least every 3 years.  Certification involves verification that procedures and practices for Risk Management Program elements are adequate and are being followed.  The audit must be performed by a team, with at least one person who is knowledgeable in the process.  A report must be generated that documents deficiencies and corrections.

Typical documentation should include completed compliance audits, including evidence of how recommendations were implemented and attendance sheets from any meetings conducted to review the audit findings with employees.

Tighe & Bond conducted a compliance audit of Agri-Mark?s ammonia refrigeration system and Risk Management Program on July 8, 2002.  This audit included a visual inspection of the covered process and a review of associated paperwork.  The results of the audit were presented to Agri-Mark in a report in August 2002.

Section 12 - Incident Investigation

A thorough investigation of any incident that could or did result in a catastrophic release of highly hazardous chemicals must take place within 48 hours of the incident.  This investigation must identify the chain of events and causes of the incident and include corrective measures that can be developed and implemented.  A team must perform the investigation with at least one person knowledgeable in the process and others who have appropriate knowledge and experience; a representative of the contractor or the chemical supplier must also be part of the team if either were involved in the incident.  A complete incident report must be developed and a system mus

t be in place that addresses and communicates recommendations in a timely manner.

Typical documentation should include completed Investigation Report Forms, including evidence of how action items were implemented and attendance sheets from any meetings conducted to review the incident with employees.

Since the Risk Management Program was initiated in August 1999, there have been no incidents requiring a formal incident investigation of the ammonia refrigeration system.

Section 13 - Employee Participation

This Section outlines how employees participate in the development of the facility?s Risk Management Plan.  Employers must train their employees and inform them of findings from incident investigations and Process Hazards Analyses and of any relevant safety and health issues.  Employees must have access to all information developed in conformance with the Risk Management Plan.

All affected employees at the facility have been involved in the training and operating procedure development.  Select employees have also been involved in performing the Process Hazard Analysis.

Section 14 - Hot Work Permit

This is a permit system for all work involving flames, heat or sparks or any other activity which has the potential to cause a fire.  It includes hot work operations (e.g., welding, cutting, etc.) conducted on or near a covered process as described in the operating procedures.  

The permit satisfies the requirements of OSHA 1910.252(a), fire prevention and protection.  The permit must indicate date(s) and the object involved with the hot work.  The permit must be kept on file while hot work proceeds.

Section 15 - Contractor Safety

Employers must inform contractors of known potential fire, explosion or toxic release hazards; explain applicable provisions of the emergency action plan; develop/implement safe work practices that control the presence, entrance and exit of contract employees in covered propane storage and distribution areas; periodically evaluate contr

actor safety performance; and maintain a contractor injury and illness log.  This applies to contractors working in or around Risk Management Program covered processes who perform maintenance or repairs, help with facility turnarounds or major renovations or do specialty work (e.g., chemical suppliers, instrumentation service contractors).  Employers must obtain and evaluate contractor safety performance and programs.

Typical documentation should include criteria for evaluating contractor safety programs, how the criteria were applied, any on-site monitoring performed while contractors were working and actions taken when contractor deficiencies were found.

Contractor evaluation forms were sent to Stahlman Engineering, Mullaly Brothers and LCS.  Completed evaluation forms and other information can be found at the end of the CONTRACTOR SAFETY section of this Risk Management Plan.

Designated Agri-Mark personnel will periodically review contractor safety practices when on-site to evaluate safety performance.  A review of contractor work is performed before the contractor is released from the facility at the end of the day.

Section 16 - Emergency Response Program

An emergency action plan for the entire facility is required that satisfies the requirements of OSHA 1910.38 and 1910.120.  The plan must include procedures for handling small releases of hazardous chemicals.  Employees must be aware of the plan and trained in specific procedures.  The regulations require a written plan that addresses emergency escape procedures; procedures for employees who remain to operate critical equipment; procedures to account for all personnel; rescue and medical duties; means of reporting emergencies; and a list of persons or departments who can answer any questions.  Further, the regulations require an alarm system; an evacuation procedure; and training for new employees and for employees who are affected by any changes to the plan.

Typical documentation should include critiques

from any drills conducted, including evidence of how any recommendations were implemented and attendance sheets from any meetings conducted to review the response effort with employees.

Agri-Mark has a Comprehensive Emergency Response program for the facility which has been coordinated with the Local Emergency Planning Commission and the Middlebury Fire Department.  Representatives at Agri-Mark have met with the Middlebury Fire Department on numerous occasions to plan and coordinate actions in the event of an ammonia release.  Agri-Mark hosts a facility tour with the fire department on an annual basis to identify critical controls and hazards to firefighters.

Agri-Mark also maintains a hazardous chemical emergency response team to address chemical spills and ammonia releases at the facility.  The team has been provided with initial 24 hour Hazardous Material Technician training in accordance with 29 CFR 1910.120 and is provided with eight hours of refresher training annually.  The last refresher training was performed at Agri-Mark on February 3, 2004.

Section 17 - Confidentiality Statement

Employers must disclose all information necessary to comply with the CAP regulations and the Risk Management Program to those persons completing PSIs, PHAs, operating procedures, incident investigations, emergency planning and response and compliance audits.  If confidential business information status must be maintained, the employer can enter into confidentiality agreements with the appropriate employees.

Typical documentation should include copies of any confidentiality statements or correspondence with any employees.

EPA has made provisions to prevent disclosure of proprietary process information or formulations.  In order to obtain Confidential Business Information (CBI) status for such proprietary information, the facility must submit justification to EPA as to why the information is proprietary.  At this time, Agri-Mark has not claimed CBI status for any of the inform

ation submitted to EPA.
